Chef Sarah Jordan is celebrated for her out-of-the-box desserts that incorporate savory elements. She blends everything from crunch, creamy, warm, cold, sweet and sour to somehow balance it into a single dessert. In 2013, she was named one of Food & Wine’s “Best New Pastry Chefs in America”, one of the highest honors in the culinary world.

Sarah's restaurants

GT Fish & Oyster
Boka
Chef Jordan's caramel tart

bake Sarah's go-to indulgence at home

irish breakfast

In moderation, try a hearty Irish breakfast, which Chef Sarah calls a “heart attack on a plate.” Sausage, rashers (bacon), black pudding (meat, blood, fat, oatmeal, and bread), white pudding (same thing minus the blood), and Irish bacon.

Sarah Jordan's food tip

Play with your plating

I think my approach to plating could be considered whimsical. It needs to look good and be artistic, but obviously you need to work on flavor first. When it comes to plating I’ll try things a couple different times. Sometimes it comes together naturally and other times it may need a little extra love. But definitely experiment.

easy treat

Pavlova—a meringue made from egg whites, sugar, whipped cream and any fresh fruit. Chef Sarah Jordan says, “It’s an easy go-to and a real crowd pleaser.”

Q & A

Which Mariano’s do you shop?

I mainly shop the Roscoe Village store, especially for Sunday Fundays.

Who does the shopping for your Sunday Fundays?

I usually do it, especially if we’re having a debate on what we’re having.

When did you decide to become a chef?

I don’t know if I decided as much as I figured out that I could make a living out of doing what I love.

Do you have any advice for aspiring pastry chefs?

Keep it simple. It’s all about ratios, really. Breads and cakes aren’t too different. Just different ratios of different ingredients. Once you understand that, it’s easy. In terms of water, flour, eggs and butter it’s all different ratios.

How do you determine what would make a tasty combination?

Sometimes you try one item and eventually you realize what would work. And sometimes it doesn’t work at all. Bacon goes pretty well with most stuff.

What are your favorite sweet/savory pairings?

I love thyme and apple. It’s a really, really good combination. This week, I was messing around with blueberries and sake. It really works.

What is your favorite thing in the produce section?

I’m a sucker for corn. I love a good corn ice cream.

Why is Mariano’s is a good place for a pastry chef to shop?

They have a really wide range of produce, especially if you enjoy making pies and tarts. And they have everything you need. All the staples.

What is your favorite kind of chocolate to use?

Currently, I use a lot of Valrhona chocolate. It’s good stuff.

If you aren’t having dessert, what’s a great after dinner cocktail?

I am a whiskey girl, so I love having a nice Old Fashioned.
